greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of achiral colorings of the facets (or vertices) of a regular n-dimensional simplex using exactly k colors.
comment: For n=1, the figure is a line segment with two vertices. For n=2, the figure is a triangle with three edges. For n=3, the figure is a tetrahedron with four triangular faces. The Schläfli symbol, {3,...,3}, of the regular n-dimensional simplex consists of n-1 threes. Each of its n+1 facets is a regular (n-1)-dimensional simplex. An achiral coloring is the same as its reflection. For k <= n all the colorings are achiral.
The final zero in each row indicates no achiral colorings when each facet has a different color.
link: Robert A. Russell, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1325
formula: G.f. for row n: x * (1+x)^n - x^(n+1).
G.f. for column k>1: x^(k-1)/(1-x)^k - x^(k-1).
example: For T(3,2)=3, the tetrahedron may have one, two, or three faces of one color.
xref: Cf. A325002 (oriented), A007318(n,k-1) (unoriented), A325001 (up to k colors).
results.author: _Robert A. Russell_, Mar 23 2019
